title: Ticket #5151: Exceptions are not recorded after hung shadow processes are killed
description:
If the schedd kills a shadow because it was hung, you see the following error messages: 

07/15/15 15:12:22 (pid:1363748) Shadow pid 1890816 successfully killed because it was hung.
07/15/15 15:12:22 (pid:1363748) Shadow pid 1890816 died with signal 4 (Illegal instruction)

After this, the job stays in 'R' (I haven't figured out how long though). No shadow is restarted - I suppose the lease eventually times out?

According to the code, the intent is to record a shadow exception and have the job exit. However, here's the relevant code: 

                if ( daemonCore->Was_Not_Responding(pid) ) {
<snip/>
                        dprintf( D_ALWAYS,
                                         "%s pid %d successfully killed because it was hung.\n",
                                         name, pid );
                        status = JOB_EXCEPTION;
                }

<snip/>

                if ( WIFEXITED(status) ) {
<snip/>

For POSIX, WIFEXITED looks at the upper 8 bits. Hence, WIFEXITED returns false and HTCondor interprets this a signal. jobExitCode is not invoked and the job stays running.

I think we want to set: 

                        status = JOB_EXCEPTION << 8;

This causes the job to exit and a shadow exception recorded.

Further, I don't understand the intent of the WIFSIGNALED branch of the conditional. It seems to not update the job state. Don't have the time to poke at it right now.

(I noticed this when a CMS schedd reported 7k jobs running but only 1k shadows. According to git blame, this bug was introduced by tannenba in 1999.)
remarks:
2015-Jul-15 14:42:00 by jfrey:
I agree with the proposed change, but I can't replicate the behavior reported.

If the schedd isn't in the middle of a shutdown, then the shadow exiting via a signal should result in the job going to idle status. When I tried replicating this situation by sending a SIGKILL to the shadow, the schedd marked the job idle and attempted to reuse the claim to start a new job. That failed because the slot was still Claimed/Busy, so the schedd killed the claim.

2015-Jul-16 22:22:13 by bbockelm:
I think you're right about jobs going back to running. Even after we disabled timeouts for shadows, we still see massive issues with the wrong number of running jobs. I think #5158 is to blame.

2015-Jul-22 16:23   Check-in [45388]: Version history for hung shadow exit status bug. #5151 (By Jaime Frey )
2015-Jul-21 11:05   Check-in [45367]: Fix rewriting of hung shadow's exit status. #5151 To treat a hung shadow like it exited with the JOB_EXCEPTION exit code, we need to left-shift the value 8 in the raw status value. Otherwise, it looks like the shadow exited via a signal. (By Jaime Frey )
